Toyota Tundra 0-60 times

Autotk.com offers accurate information on Toyota Tundra 0-60 times and quarter mile from trusted sources. You may also keep track of how 0-60 times of Toyota Tundra changed across years and check out the model’s competitors with the same acceleration performance.

Our mission is to present an easy-to-read and comprehensive information on Toyota Tundra 0-60 mph and quarter mile for the devoted geeks, as it is an essential indicator of the vehicle power.

Toyota Tundra competitors' 0-60 mph acceleration

  • Chevrolet Silverado 1500 0-60

    • 0-60 5.7 - 6.4 sec
    • quarter mile 14.3 @ 98 - 14.9 @ 93 mph

  • RAM 1500 0-60

    • 0-60 5.9 - 7.4 sec
    • quarter mile 14.2 @ 100 - 15.8 @ 84 mph

  • GMC Sierra 1500 0-60

    • 0-60 6.3 - 7.3 sec
    • quarter mile 14.7 @ 93 - 15.9 @ 91 mph

In the auto sector of modern trucks, Toyota Tundra is designed to put Detroit Three to a challenge. Toyota Tundra is now fully V-8 and comes in several models from the Platinum models, to the base SR, and the exotic 1794 Edition, "which are the range-topping trims."

To the truck enthusiasts, it is good to know that Toyota makes Tundra in the variant of TRD Pro.
 

0-60 mph Progress and Competitors

Since the push button start is not a luxury, you can enjoy in Tundra, insert the key into the ignition slot, turn it and Toyota’s i-Force 32-valve V-8 roars to life.

From the time of its debut in 2007, the aluminum 5.7-liter V-8 has not been altered in design, and the sound of the hydraulic power cooling fan is a reminder of that fact.

The Tundra is a good fit for 401 lb-ft of torque, generating 381 of horsepower, just enough to take the 5858-pounds of Tundra from 0- 60 mph in 6.4 seconds and makes the quarter mile in 15.1 seconds.

The figures are a match for the new vehicle, Nissan Titan Pro-4X, which records the same 60 mph and beats the Titan in the quarter mile by 0.1 seconds. Tundra is not a good match for the best selling trucks, no doubt.

Chevrolet Silverado tested in 2015, comes with 420-hp 6.2-liter V-8,  made the 0-60 mph in 5.7 seconds and achieved the quarter mile in 14.3 seconds. Also, Ford F-150 with 365-horsepower, 3.5-liter twin-turbocharged V-6, makes the 0-60 mph in 5.6 seconds and reached the quarter mile in 14.4 seconds.
 

Engine specifications

Toyota rebranded the Tundra for the 2014 model, with a lovely front fascia, and a host of other stylish features like the new tailgate.

The Tundra comes with new variants like the 1794 Edition that includes, 'heated and ventilated front seats, perforated leather upholstery, a chrome grille, 20-inch alloy wheels, navigation, and a JBL audio system.'

Another trim of Tundra is the TRD Pro, with suspense setup that is turned off-road, skid plates, TRD dual exhaust system, and Bilstein shocks.

The 4.0-liter V-6 standard design was discarded from 2015 onward, thereby making the 4.7-liter V-8 the standard new engine.
 

Exterior and Interior Designs

The Tundra received a face-lift in 2014 and dropped the V-6 engine in 2015, with minor changes in 2017 models. The tow-hitch receiver becomes the standard in the subsequent designs of Tundra.

The Limited models come with additional features like the power-adjustable seats in the front and with the crew cab is the optional power sunroof.

With the SR models, you have the luxury of more colors, black paint, the Super White, and the flashy Barcelona Red Metallic. The SR5 and the Limited had six more colors. The TRD Pro makes up for its lost colors with the red trim.
 

The Verdict

Like others in the Toyota fleet of vehicles, the Tundra is known for its long-term durability and reliability. Also, the TRD Pro is handy with its extreme off-road potential.

Tundra is arguably one of the oldest trucks in the market today, compared to its competitors, although, it powertrain lags behind the competitors and its interior is not classy enough compared to other half-ton trucks.

 

 

CarAndDriver Test Results

Tested vehicle: 2014 Toyota Tundra Limited 5.7L 4x4 CrewMax

Zero to 60 mph: 6.4 sec
Zero to 100 mph: 17.9 sec
Rolling start, 5-60 mph: 6.7 sec
Top gear, 30-50 mph: 3.4 sec
Top gear, 50-70 mph: 4.4 sec
Standing ¼-mile: 15.1 sec @ 93 mph
Top speed (governor limited): 107 mph
Braking, 70-0 mph: 198 ft
